[[Philip I of Castile|Philip the Handsome]] was granted his majority and became ruler of the disputed territories. |- | 19 August || [[Frederick III, Holy Roman Emperor|Frederick III]] bled to death following the amputation of his infected left leg. |- | rowspan="4" valign="top" | [[1494]] || 25 January || [[Ferdinand I of Naples]] died of colorectal cancer. He was succeeded as [[king]] of [[Kingdom of Naples|Naples]] by his son [[Alfonso II of Naples]]. |- | 16 March || [[Maximilian I, Holy Roman Emperor|Maximilian]] married [[Bianca Maria Sforza]], the niece of [[Ludovico Sforza]], the [[regent]] of [[Duchy of Milan|Milan]], receiving a dowry of four hundred thousand [[ducat]]s. |- | 21 October || [[Gian Galeazzo Sforza]], the [[duke]] of [[Duchy of Milan|Milan]], died, probably poisoned on the orders of his uncle and [[regent]] [[Ludovico Sforza]]. |- | 22 October || [[Ludovico Sforza]] was crowned [[duke]] of [[Duchy of Milan|Milan]] over the objection of [[Alfonso II of Naples]], the [[king]] of [[Kingdom of Naples|Naples]], who claimed the duchy by his daughter's marriage to the previous duke [[Gian Galeazzo Sforza]]. Ludovico Sforza invited [[Charles VIII of France]], the king of [[Kingdom of France|France]], to pass through Milanese territory on the way to a planned invasion of Naples. |- | rowspan="4" valign="top" | [[1495]] || 2 February || ''[[Diet of Worms (1495)]]'': A session of the [[Imperial Diet (Holy Roman Empire)|Imperial Diet]] opened at [[Worms, Germany]]. |- | February || ''[[Italian War of 1494–1498]]'': [[Kingdom of France|French]] forces conquered the [[Kingdom of Naples|Neapolitan]] capital [[Naples]]. |- | 31 March || ''Italian War of 1494–1498'': The [[Papal States]], [[Republic of Venice|Venice]], [[Kingdom of Aragon|Aragon]] and [[Kingdom of Sicily|Sicily]] and the [[Holy Roman Empire]] established the League of Venice, an anti-[[Kingdom of France|French]] military alliance. |- | 7 August || ''Diet of Worms (1495)'': The [[Imperial Diet (Holy Roman Empire)|Diet]] concluded with the publication of three major reforms to the constitution of the [[Holy Roman Empire]]. The ''[[Ewiger Landfriede]]'' banned the use of violence to resolve disputes between the lesser [[nobility]]. The ''[[Reichskammergericht]]'', a permanent high court which heard civil cases, was established. The [[Common Penny]], a tax reform, was passed, which established a [[poll tax]], [[income tax]] and [[property tax]] on all residents of the Empire. |- | rowspan="2" valign="top" | [[1496]] || || The [[Judaism|Jews]] were expelled from [[Duchy of Styria|Styria]] and [[Wiener Neustadt]]. |- | 20 October || [[Philip I of Castile|Philip the Handsome]] married [[Joanna of Castile]], the third child of [[Isabella I of Castile]], the [[queen regnant]] of [[Kingdom of Castile|Castile]], and [[Ferdinand II of Aragon]], the [[king]] of [[Kingdom of Aragon|Aragon]]. |- | [[1497]] || 4 October || [[John, Prince of Asturias]], the [[heir apparent]] to the thrones of [[Kingdom of Castile|Castile]] and [[Kingdom of Aragon|Aragon]], died without issue. His older sister [[Isabella of Aragon, Queen of Portugal]] succeeded as heir apparent. |- | rowspan="2" valign="top" | [[1498]] || 7 April || ''Italian War of 1494–1498'': [[Charles VIII of France]], the [[king]] of [[Kingdom of France|France]], died, probably from an epidural hematoma after bumping his head on a doorframe, effectively ending the war. |- | 23 August || [[Isabella of Aragon, Queen of Portugal]], the [[heir apparent]] to the thrones of [[Kingdom of Castile|Castile]] and [[Kingdom of Aragon|Aragon]], died giving birth to a son, [[Miguel da Paz, Prince of Portugal]], who became the new heir to the two thrones. |- | rowspan="8" valign="top" | [[1499]] || 20 January || ''[[Swabian War]]'': [[Holy Roman Empire|Imperial]] and [[Swabian League]] forces occupied the [[Val Müstair]], a strategically important pass in the [[Three Leagues]]. |- | 20 February || ''[[Battle of Hard]]'': A [[Old Swiss Confederacy|Swiss]] force routed a [[Holy Roman Empire]] army at [[Hard, Austria]]. |- | 22 March || ''[[Battle of Bruderholz]]'': A [[Swabian League]] raiding party was surprised and defeated by a numerically inferior [[Old Swiss Confederacy|Swiss]] force near [[Basel]]. |- | 11 April || ''[[Battle of Schwaderloh]]'': The [[Old Swiss Confederacy|Swiss]] surprised and defeated a significantly larger [[Swabian League]] force as they burned and looted the area around [[Triboltingen]]. |- | 20 April || ''[[Battle of Frastanz]]'': [[Old Swiss Confederacy|Swiss]] troops flanked a [[Swabian League|Swabian]] ''[[Letzi]]'' in the [[Montafon]] and drove out their forces. |- | 22 May || ''[[Battle of Calven]]'': An Austrian force in the [[Val Müstair]] was attacked simultaneously in the front and rear by [[Three Leagues]] forces. Nearly half were killed, and the rest fled. |- | 22 July || ''[[Battle of Dornach]]'': A [[Old Swiss Confederacy|Swiss]] force dispersed a division of the [[Holy Roman Empire]] near [[Dornach]], with heavy losses on both sides. The Imperial commander was killed. |- | 22 September || ''Swabian War'': The [[Swabian League]] and the [[Old Swiss Confederacy]] signed the [[Treaty of Basel (1499)|Treaty of Basel]], ending the war. An [[imperial ban]] placed on the Swiss cantons following their refusal to pay the [[Common Penny]] was revoked. |- | rowspan="2" valign="top" | [[1500]] || || An [[Imperial Diet (Holy Roman Empire)|Imperial Diet]] at [[Augsburg]] established six [[Imperial Circle|imperial circles]], administrative divisions over many of the [[Imperial Estate|states]] of the [[Holy Roman Empire]], in order to better organize military forces and tax collection in the Empire. It also established an [[Imperial Government]], a permanent government seated at [[Nuremberg]] composed of representatives of twenty [[princes of the Holy Roman Empire|princes]] of the Empire. |- | 19 July || [[Miguel da Paz, Prince of Portugal]], the infant heir to the thrones of [[Kingdom of Castile|Castile]] and [[Kingdom of Aragon|Aragon]], died. His aunt [[Joanna of Castile]] became the new [[heir apparent]]. |} == 16th century == {| class="wikitable" width="100%" ! style="width: 6%;" | Year || style="width: 10%;" | Date || Event |- | [[1502]] || || [[Maximilian I, Holy Roman Emperor|Maximilian]] dissolved the [[Imperial Government]] of the [[Holy Roman Empire]]. |- | [[1504]] || 26 November || [[Isabella I of Castile]], the [[queen regnant|queen]] of [[Kingdom of Castile|Castile]], died. She was succeeded by her daughter, [[Philip I of Castile|Philip the Handsome's]] wife, [[Joanna of Castile]]. The Castilian nobility refused the regency of [[Ferdinand II of Aragon]], [[king]] of [[Kingdom of Aragon|Aragon]], Isabella's widower and father to the purportedly mentally ill Joanna, and summoned Philip to take the throne. |- | rowspan="4" valign="top" | [[1506]] || January || [[Philip I of Castile|Philip the Handsome]] was shipwrecked off the coast of [[Dorset]] on his way to claim the throne of [[Kingdom of Castile|Castile]] and taken into the custody of [[Henry VII of England]], the [[king]] of [[Kingdom of England|England]]. |- | 30 April || [[Philip I of Castile|Philip the Handsome]] and [[Henry VII of England]], the [[king]] of [[Kingdom of England|England]], signed the ''[[Malus Intercursus]]'', under which the former agreed to return to the latter all [[House of York|Yorkist]] fugitives in [[Duchy of Burgundy|Burgundy]] and to open Burgundy completely to English trade in textiles. |- | 28 June || [[Philip I of Castile|Philip the Handsome]] signed the [[Treaty of Villafáfila]], under which he recognized the incapacity of his wife [[Joanna of Castile]], and was recognized in turn by his father-in-law [[Ferdinand II of Aragon]], [[king]] of [[Kingdom of Aragon|Aragon]], as ''[[jure uxoris]]'' king of [[Kingdom of Castile|Castile]] and lord of the [[Spanish West Indies]]. |- | 25 September || [[Philip I of Castile|Philip the Handsome]] died of typhoid at [[Burgos]]. He was succeeded as [[duke]] of [[Duchy of Burgundy|Burgundy]] by his young son [[Charles V, Holy Roman Emperor]]. |- | [[1508]] || 4 February || [[Maximilian I, Holy Roman Emperor|Maximilian]] took the title elected [[Holy Roman Emperor]] at [[Trento]]. |- | [[1517]] || 31 October || [[Martin Luther]], a professor of moral theology at the University of Wittenberg, now part of the [[Martin Luther University of Halle-Wittenberg]], published the ''[[Ninety-five Theses]]'', which criticized the [[Catholic Church|Church]] practice of selling [[indulgence]]s. |- | rowspan="2" valign="top" | [[1519]] || 12 January || [[Maximilian I, Holy Roman Emperor|Maximilian]] died. He was succeeded as [[archduke]] of Austria by his grandson [[Charles V, Holy Roman Emperor]], [[king]] of [[Spain]] and [[duke]] of [[Duchy of Burgundy|Burgundy]]. |- | 28 June || ''[[Imperial election, 1519]]'': [[Charles V, Holy Roman Emperor|Charles]] was elected [[Holy Roman Emperor]]. |} == 17th century == {| class="wikitable" width="100%" ! style="width: 6%;" | Year || style="width: 10%;" | Date || Event |- | [[1601]] || 3 August || ''[[Battle of Guruslău]]'': A force of [[Kingdom of Hungary (1526–1867)|Hungarians]], [[Wallachia]]ns and [[Cossacks]] defeated the rebel [[Principality of Transylvania (1570–1711)|Transylvanian]] [[prince of Transylvania|prince]] [[Sigismund Báthory]] on the plain of the [[Guruslău River]]. |- | [[1604]] || 28 September || ''[[Bocskai uprising]]'': The [[Kingdom of Hungary (1526–1867)|Hungarian]] [[Hungarian nobility|nobleman]] [[Stephen Bocskai]] launched a revolt against [[House of Habsburg|Habsburg]] dominion over Hungary. |- | rowspan="2" valign="top" | [[1606]] || 23 June || ''Bocskai uprising'': The [[Kingdom of Hungary (1526–1867)|Hungarian]] [[Hungarian nobility|nobleman]] [[Stephen Bocskai]] and [[Rudolf II, Holy Roman Emperor]], the [[Holy Roman Emperor]], [[king]] of [[Kingdom of Bohemia|Bohemia]], [[Kingdom of Hungary|Hungary]] and [[Kingdom of Croatia (Habsburg)|Croatia]] and [[archduke]] of Austria, signed the [[Treaty of Vienna (1606)|Treaty of Vienna]], naming the former [[Prince of Transylvania|prince]] of [[Principality of Transylvania (1570–1711)|Transylvania]] and granting some additional rights to religious minorities in Hungary. |- | 11 November || ''[[Long Turkish War]]'': The [[Peace of Zsitvatorok]] was signed in what is now [[Radvaň nad Dunajom]], ending a long conflict between the [[Ottoman Empire]] and the [[Holy Roman Empire]]. The obligations of the [[Kingdom of Hungary (1526–1867)|Hungarian]] [[Hungarian nobility|nobility]] to their Ottoman [[suzerainty|suzerains]] were reduced. |- | [[1608]] || 25 June || [[Rudolf II, Holy Roman Emperor|Rudolf's]] younger brother [[Matthias, Holy Roman Emperor]], the [[governor]] of Austria, with the support of the nobility in Austria, [[Kingdom of Hungary|Hungary]] and [[Moravia]], forced him to cede the rule of those lands. |} == 18th century == {| class="wikitable" width="100%" ! style="width: 6%;" | Year || style="width: 10%;" | Date || Event |- | rowspan="3" valign="top" | [[1701]] || 9 July || ''[[Battle of Carpi]]'': An Austrian army dispatched a small [[Kingdom of France|French]] force at Carpi, near [[Legnago]], during its crossing into [[Italian Peninsula|Italy]]. |- | 1 September || ''[[Battle of Chiari]]'': An Austrian force dealt severe and disproportionate casualties to a [[Kingdom of France|French]] army attempting to dislodge it at [[Chiari, Lombardy]]. |- | 7 September || [[Kingdom of England|England]], the [[Holy Roman Empire]] and the [[Dutch Republic]] signed the [[Treaty of The Hague (1701)|Treaty of The Hague]], reestablishing the [[Grand Alliance (League of Augsburg)|Grand Alliance]] and setting out their primary goals: the establishment of Austrian control over [[Spain|Spanish]] territories in [[Italian Peninsula|Italy]] and the [[Spanish Netherlands]] and Dutch and English access to markets in the [[Spanish Empire]]. |- | rowspan="2" valign="top" | [[1702]] || 1 February || ''[[Battle of Cremona]]'': Austrian forces entered the [[Kingdom of France|French]]-held city of [[Cremona]] but, failing to take the citadel of the city and facing the arrival of French reinforcements, withdrew. |- | 15 August || ''[[Battle of Luzzara]]'': An Austrian force under the [[general]] [[Prince Eugene of Savoy]] crossed the [[Po (river)|Po]] at [[Luzzara]] but failed to dislodge the [[Kingdom of France|French]] from their position despite heavy casualties on both sides. |} == 19th century == {| class="wikitable" width="100%" ! style="width: 6%;" | Year || style="width: 10%;" | Date || Event |- | [[1801]] || 9 February || ''[[War of the Second Coalition]]'': [[French First Republic|France]] and [[Francis II, Holy Roman Emperor]], the latter acting as [[Holy Roman Emperor|emperor]] of the [[Holy Roman Empire]] and as [[king]] of [[Kingdom of Hungary (1526–1867)|Hungary]], [[Kingdom of Bohemia|Bohemia]] and [[Kingdom of Croatia (Habsburg)|Croatia]] and [[archduke]] of Austria, signed the [[Treaty of Lunéville]], ending their conflict. France made territorial gains, including the extension of its border with the Holy Roman Empire east to the [[Rhine]]. |- | [[1804]] || 11 August || [[Francis II, Holy Roman Emperor|Francis]] took the title [[Emperor of Austria]]. |- | rowspan="3" valign="top" | [[1805]] || 25 September || ''[[Ulm Campaign]]'': A [[First French Empire|French]]-[[Electorate of Bavaria|Bavarian]] force crossed the [[Rhine]] into Germany. |- | 8 October || ''[[Battle of Wertingen]]'': A [[First French Empire|French]] army surprised and defeated a much smaller Austrian force at [[Wertingen]]. |- | 9 October || ''[[Battle of Günzburg]]'': A [[First French Empire|French]] force captured a [[Danube]] river crossing at [[Günzburg]]. Austrian forces failed to retake it, suffering heavy casualties, and withdrew. |} == 20th century == {| class="wikitable" width="100%" ! style="width: 6%;" | Year || style="width: 10%;" | Date || Event |- | rowspan="3" valign="top" | [[1901]] || 18 January || ''[[Cisleithanian legislative election, 1900–01]]'': The last round of elections were held to the [[Imperial Council (Austria)|Imperial Council]]. [[Ethnic nationalism|Ethnic nationalist]] parties won the majority of seats. |- | 2 October || ''[[Hungarian parliamentary election, 1901]]'': Voting began in elections to the [[Lands of the Crown of Saint Stephen|Hungarian]] [[Diet of Hungary|Diet]]. |- | 9 October || ''Hungarian parliamentary election, 1901'': Voting ended. The [[classical liberalism|liberal]] [[Liberal Party (Hungary)|Liberal Party]] won a supermajority of seats. |- | rowspan="2" valign="top" | [[1907]] || 14 May || ''[[Cisleithanian legislative election, 1907]]'': The first round of elections was held to the [[Imperial Council (Austria)|Imperial Council]]. |- | 23 May || ''Cisleithanian legislative election, 1907'': The runoff elections to the [[Imperial Council (Austria)|Imperial Council]] were held. The [[conservatism|conservative]] [[Christian Social Party (Austria)|Christian Social Party]] won a plurality of seats. |} == 21st century == {| class="wikitable" width="100%" ! style="width: 6%;" | Year || style="width: 10%;" | Date || Event |- | rowspan="4" valign="top" | [[2002]] || August || ''[[2002 European floods]]'': Heavy rains resulted in destructive flooding in [[Salzburg (state)|Salzburg]] and [[Upper Austria]]. |- | 7 September || ''[[Knittelfeld Putsch]]'': An agreement between [[Jörg Haider]], [[Landeshauptmann]] of [[Carinthia]] and an elder statesman of the [[Freedom Party of Austria|Freedom Party of Austria (FPÖ)]], and [[Susanne Riess]], the party chair, was symbolically torn up at a party meeting at [[Knittelfeld]]. |- | 8 September || ''Knittelfeld Putsch'': [[Susanne Riess|Riess]], [[finance minister]] [[Karl-Heinz Grasser]], and [[Peter Westenthaler]], until then chairman of the party's caucus in [[Austrian Parliament|Parliament]], resigned from the [[Freedom Party of Austria|FPÖ]]. |- | 24 November || ''[[Austrian legislative election, 2002]]'': The [[Christian democracy|Christian democratic]] [[Austrian People's Party|Austrian People's Party (ÖVP)]] gained twenty-seven seats in elections to the [[National Council (Austria)|National Council]], largely at the expense of the [[Freedom Party of Austria|FPÖ]]. |- | [[2004]] || 25 April || ''[[Austrian presidential election, 2004]]'': [[Heinz Fischer]] of the [[social democracy|social democratic]] [[Social Democratic Party of Austria|Social Democratic Party of Austria (SPÖ)]] was elected [[president of Austria|president]] with fifty-two percent of the vote.{{cite web|title=Heinz fischer is elected president of the republic|url=https://www.robert-schuman.eu/en/eem/0295-heinz-fischer-is-elected-president-of-the-republic}} |} == References == {{reflist|2}} [[Category:Timelines by country|Austria]] [[Category:History of Austria| ]]

{{Infobox scientist | image = Touraj Atabaki high resolution.jpg | image_size = 150px | name = Touraj Atabaki | caption = Atabaki in 2009 | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1950|02|23|df=y}} | birth_place = [[Tehran]], [[Iran]] | alma_mater = {{plainlist| *[[National University of Iran]] *[[University of London]] *[[Utrecht University]] }} | fields = [[Social history]] | workplaces = {{plainlist| *[[Utrecht University]] *[[International Institute of Social History]] *[[University of Amsterdam]] *[[Leiden University]] }} | thesis_title = Ethnicity and Autonomy in Iranian Azarbayjan: the Autonomous government of Azarbayjan 1946 | thesis_url = http://hoogleraren.leidenuniv.nl/id/3364 | thesis_year = 1991 | doctoral_advisor = [[Ervand Abrahamian]] | citizenship = [[Iranians in the Netherlands|Iranian–Dutch]] | website = {{url|atabaki.nl}} }} '''Touraj Atabaki''' ({{lang-fa|تورج اتابکی}}, born February 23, 1950 in [[Tehran]]) is the Senior Research Fellow at the [[International Institute of Social History]] in [[Amsterdam]].<ref name=conau>{{citation|url=http://www.encyclopedia.com/article-1G2-2284600019/atabaki-touraj-1950.html|title=Atabaki, Touraj 1950-|work=[[Contemporary Authors]]|accessdate=2017-11-02}}</ref> He also holds the chair of the Social History of the Middle East and Central Asia at the School of Middle East Studies of [[Leiden University]],<ref name=leiden>{{citation|url=http://hoogleraren.leidenuniv.nl/id/3364|title=Touraj Atabaki|work=Leidse hoogleraren vanaf 1575|publisher=Leiden University|accessdate=2017-11-07}}</ref> and is past president of the [[Association for Iranian Studies]]<ref>{{citation|url=http://associationforiranianstudies.org/about/officers/2017|title=2017 Officers|publisher=Association for Iranian Studies|accessdate=2017-11-07}}</ref> and the European Society for Central Asian Studies.<ref name=conau/>
Atabaki earned his doctorate from [[Utrecht University]] in 1991 with a dissertation titled ''Ethnicity and autonomy in Iranian Azarbayjan : the autonomous government of Azarbayjan 1946''.<ref name=leiden/>
==Books== Atabaki's books include: *''Iran in the 20th Century: Historiography and Political Culture'' (I. B. Tauris, 2009)<ref>Review of ''Iran in the 20th century'': *Ali Gheissari (2011), ''Iranian Studies'' 44 (6): 913–917, {{doi|10.1080/00210862.2011.586815}}.</ref> *''The State and the Subaltern: Modernization, Society and the State in Turkey and Iran'' (edited, I. B. Tauris, 2007)<ref>Reviews of ''The State and the Subaltern: Modernization, Society and the State in Turkey and Iran'': *Feroz Ahmad (May 2008), ''Journal of Islamic Studies'' 19 (2): 271–273, {{doi|10.1093/jis/etn007}}; *David Mason (2010), ''MELA Notes'' 83: 69–72, {{jstor|29785938}}.</ref> *''Iran and the First World War: Battleground of the Great Powers'' (edited, I. B. Tauris, 2006) *''Men of Order: Authoritarian Modernization under Atatürk and Reza Shah'' (I. B. Tauris, 2004)<ref>Reviews of ''Men of Order: Authoritarian Modernization under Atatürk and Reza Shah'': *Afshin Marashi (June 2006), ''Iranian Studies'' 39 (2): 287–290, {{jstor|4311824}}; *C. Dodd (2006), ''Journal of Islamic Studies'' 17 (1): 91–92, {{doi|10.1093/jis/eti187}}.</ref> *''Azerbaijan: Ethnicity and the Struggle for Power in Iran'' (I. B. Tauris, 2000)<ref>Review of ''Azerbaijan: Ethnicity and the Struggle for Power in Iran'': *Mary Zeng (2014), ''Journal of the Ottoman and Turkish Studies Association'' 1 (1-2): 257–260, {{doi|10.2979/jottturstuass.1.1-2.257}}.</ref> *''Post-Soviet Central Asia'' (with John O'Kane, I. B. Tauris, 1998)<ref>Review of ''Post-Soviet Central Asia'': *Anoushiravan Ehteshami (Winter 1999), ''Slavic Review'' 58 (4): 908–909, {{doi|10.2307/2697225}}.</ref> *''Azerbaijan: Ethnicity and Autonomy in Twentieth-Century Iran'' (British Academic Press, 1993)<ref>Reviews of ''Azerbaijan: Ethnicity and Autonomy in Twentieth-century Iran'': *Adeeb Khalid (1995), ''Slavic Review'' 54 (3): 819–820, {{doi|10.2307/2501826}}; *Houri Berberian (Summer–Autumn 1996), ''Iranian Studies'' 29 (3/4): 367–371, {{jstor|4311003}}.</ref>

[[Lyndon B. Johnson|Lyndon Johnson]] |term_start2 = December 4, 1961 |term_end2 = March 31, 1966 |predecessor2 = [[George C. McGhee|George McGhee]] |successor2 = [[Henry D. Owen|Henry Owen]] |office3 = [[Deputy National Security Advisor (United States)|Deputy National Security Advisor]] |president3 = [[John F. Kennedy]] |term_start3 = January 20, 1961 |term_end3 = December 4, 1961 |predecessor3 = Position established |successor3 = [[Carl Kaysen]] |birth_date = {{birth date|1916|10|7}} |birth_place = {{nowrap|[[New York City]], [[New York (state)|New York]], [[United States|U.S.]]}} |death_date = {{death date and age|2003|2|13|1916|10|7}} |death_place = [[Austin, Texas|Austin]], [[Texas]], [[United States|U.S.]] |party = [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic]] |spouse = [[Elspeth Rostow|Elspeth Davies]] |children = 2 |alma_mater = [[Yale University]] {{small|([[Bachelor of Arts|BA]], [[Master of Arts|MA]], [[Doctor of Philosophy|PhD]])}}
[[Balliol College, Oxford]] {{small|([[Bachelor of Letters|BLitt]])}} }} '''Walt Whitman Rostow''' (also known as '''Walt Rostow''' or '''W.W. Rostow''') {{post-nominals|country=GBR|sep=,|OBE}} (October 7, 1916 – February 13, 2003) was an American [[economist]] and political theorist who served as [[National Security Advisor (United States)|Special Assistant for National Security Affairs]] to [[President of the United States|US President]] [[Lyndon B. Johnson]] from 1966 to 1969.{{cite news |author= |title=The Cold Warrior Who Never Apologized |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/09/08/opinion/vietnam-walt-rostow.html |quote= |newspaper=[[New York Times]] |date=September 8, 2017}}{{cite news |author= |title=Voice of U.S. Policy. Walt Whitman Rostow |url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9B0DE4DC143AE63ABC4B52DFB266838C679EDE&legacy=true |quote= |newspaper=[[New York Times]] |date=April 13, 1967 }} Prominent for his role in the shaping of [[US foreign policy]] in Southeast Asia during the 1960s, he was a staunch [[anti-communist]], noted for a belief in the efficacy of [[capitalism]] and [[free enterprise]], strongly supporting [[US involvement in the Vietnam War]]. Rostow is known for his book ''[[Rostow's stages of growth|The Stages of Economic Growth: A Non-Communist Manifesto]]'' (1960), which was used in several fields of [[social science]]. His older brother [[Eugene V. Rostow|Eugene Rostow]] also held a number of high government foreign policy posts. ==Early life== Rostow was born in [[Manhattan, New York City]], to a Russian Jewish immigrant family. His parents, Lillian (Helman) and Victor Rostow,http://oxfordindex.oup.com/viewindexcard/10.1093$002fanb$002f9780198606697.article.1401158 were active [[socialist]]s, and named Walt after [[Walt Whitman]]. His brother [[Eugene Rostow|Eugene]], named for [[Eugene V. Debs]], became a legal scholar, and his brother Ralph, after [[Ralph Waldo Emerson]], a department store manager. Rostow entered [[Yale University]] at age 15 on a full scholarship, graduated at 19, and completed his [[Doctor of Philosophy|Ph.D.]] there in 1940. He also won a [[Rhodes Scholarship]] to study at [[Balliol College|Balliol College, Oxford]], where he completed a B.Litt. degree. In 1936, during the [[Edward VIII abdication crisis]], he assisted broadcaster [[Alistair Cooke]], who reported on the events for the [[NBC]] radio network. After completing his education, he started teaching economics at [[Columbia University]]. ==Professional and academic career== During [[World War II]], Rostow served in the [[Office of Strategic Services]] under [[William Joseph Donovan]]. Among other tasks, he participated in selecting targets for US bombardment. [[Nicholas Katzenbach]] would later joke: "I finally understand the difference between Walt and me [...] I was the navigator who was shot down and spent two years in a German prison camp, and Walt was the guy picking my targets." In 1945, immediately after the war, Rostow became assistant chief of the German-Austrian Economic Division in the [[United States Department of State]] in Washington, D.C. In 1946, he returned to Oxford as the [[Harold Vyvyan Harmsworth Professor of American History]]. In 1947, he became the assistant to the Executive Secretary of the [[Economic Commission for Europe]], and was involved in the development of the [[Marshall Plan]]. Rostow spent a year at [[University of Cambridge|Cambridge University]] as the [[Pitt Professor of American History and Institutions]]. He was professor of [[economic history]] at the [[Massachusetts Institute of Technology]] (MIT) from 1950 to 1961, and a staff member of the [[MIT Center for International Studies|Center for International Studies]] (CIS) at [[Massachusetts Institute of Technology|MIT]] from 1951 to 1961. From late 1951 to August 1952, Rostow headed the Soviet Vulnerabilities Project. The project, which was sponsored by CIS and received significant support from the U.S. government, sought to identify Soviet vulnerabilities to political/psychological warfare, and received contributions from top [[Sovietologist]] and psychological warfare specialists.{{cite book|last=Mitrovich|first=Gregory|title=Undermining the Kremlin: America's Strategy to Subvert the Soviet Bloc, 1947-1956|date=2000|publisher=Cornell University Press|isbn=0801437113|pages=[https://books.google.no/books?id=w6TVdT-q7vcC&pg=PA117 117–120]|language=en}} In June 1955, Rostow headed a group of stalwart cold warriors called the ''[[Quantico, Virginia|Quantico]] Vulnerabilities Panel'' which issued a report{{cite web|title=REPORT OF THE QUANTICO VULNERABILITIES PANEL|url=https://archive.org/details/REPORTOFTHEQUANTICOVULNERABILITIESPANEL86B00269R0008000700015|website=archive.org|date=June 10, 1955}} advocating nuclear coercion toward the Soviet Union. Although the experts were invited by [[Nelson Rockefeller]], their proposal ran contrary to the policy of the Eisenhower administration.{{cite book|last=Mitrovich|first=Gregory|title=Undermining the Kremlin: America's Strategy to Subvert the Soviet Bloc, 1947-1956|date=2000|publisher=Cornell University Press|isbn=0801437113|pages=[https://books.google.no/books?id=w6TVdT-q7vcC&pg=PA169 169–171]|language=en}} In 1954, Rostow advised President [[Dwight Eisenhower]] on economic and foreign policy, and in 1958 he became a speechwriter for him. In August 1954, Rostow and fellow [[Central Intelligence Agency|CIA]]-connected MIT economics professor [[Max F. Millikan]] convinced Eisenhower to massively increase US foreign aid for development as part of a policy of spreading American-style capitalist [[economic growth]] in Asia and elsewhere, backed by the military.http://www.american.edu/spa/ccps/upload/Tama-Eisenhower-paper.pdf{{cite web |url=http://www.cia-on-campus.org/mit.edu/max.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2013-08-06 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20130802001502/http://www.cia-on-campus.org/mit.edu/max.html |archivedate=2013-08-02 |df= }} {{cite web |url=http://www.cia-on-campus.org/mit.edu/max.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2013-08-06 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20130802001502/http://www.cia-on-campus.org/mit.edu/max.html |archivedate=2013-08-02 |df= }} ==Involvement with the Israeli nuclear program== While working as national security advisor, Rostow became involved in setting the [[Israel–United States relations|United States' posture towards Israel]]. Although he supported military and economic assistance to Israel, Rostow believed that increased public alignment between the two states could run counter to US diplomatic and oil interests in the region. After reviewing the May 1967 report from the Atomic Energy Commission team that had inspected Dimona along with other intelligence, Rostow informed President Johnson that, though the team found [[Nuclear weapons and Israel|no evidence of a nuclear weapons program]], "there are enough unanswered questions to make us want to avoid getting locked in too closely with Israel." Concerns about Israel's nuclear program were tabled by the United States during the build-up to the [[Six-Day War]] and its aftermath. Though Rostow, Johnson, and Secretary of State [[Dean Rusk]] tried to convince Israel not to resort to military force, they supported Israel once the war began. When the nuclear issue resurfaced in January 1968, just prior to Prime Minister [[Levi Eshkol]]'s visit to the United States, Rostow recommended that the president make it clear that the United States expected Israel to sign the NPT.{{cite web|url=http://www.wilsoncenter.org/walt-rostow|title=Walt Rostow - Wilson Center|work=wilsoncenter.org}} ==''The Stages of Economic Growth''== {{Main article|Rostow's stages of growth}} In 1960, Rostow published ''The Stages of Economic Growth: A Non-Communist Manifesto'', which proposed the Rostovian take-off model of economic growth, one of the major historical models of economic growth, which argues that economic modernization occurs in five basic stages of varying length: traditional society, preconditions for take-off, take-off, drive to maturity, and high [[mass consumption]]. This became one of the important concepts in the [[Modernization theory|theory of modernization]] in [[social evolutionism]]. Rostow's thesis was criticized at the time and subsequently as universalizing a model of Western development that could not be replicated in places like Latin America or sub-Saharan Africa. The book impressed presidential candidate [[John F. Kennedy]], who appointed Rostow as one of his political advisers, and sought his advice.{{cite book|author=Marc J. Selverstone|title=A Companion to John F. Kennedy|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=bZ8yAwAAQBAJ&pg=PT277|date=24 March 2014|publisher=Wiley|isbn=978-1-118-60886-9|pages=277–}} When Kennedy became president in 1961, he appointed Rostow as deputy to his national security assistant [[McGeorge Bundy]]. Later that year, Rostow became [[Director of Policy Planning|Director]] of the State Department's [[Policy Planning Staff (United States)|Policy Planning Staff]]. After [[Assassination of John F. Kennedy|Kennedy's assassination]], his successor Lyndon B. Johnson promoted Rostow to Bundy's job after he wrote Johnson's first [[State of the Union]] speech. As national security adviser, Rostow was responsible for developing the government's policy in Vietnam, and was convinced that the war could be won, becoming Johnson's main war hawk and playing an important role in bringing Johnson's presidency to an end.[https://www.nytimes.com/2017/09/08/opinion/vietnam-walt-rostow.html?mcubz=1 Vietnam Walter Rostow] When [[Richard Nixon]] became president, Rostow left office, and over the next thirty years taught economics at the [[Lyndon B. Johnson School of Public Affairs]] at the [[University of Texas at Austin]] with his wife [[Elspeth Rostow]], who later became dean of the school. He wrote extensively in defense of free enterprise economics, particularly in [[developing nations]]. ==Honors and awards== Rostow received the [[Order of the British Empire]] (1945), the [[Legion of Merit]] (1945), and the [[Presidential Medal of Freedom]] (1969). ==Works== * ''Investment and the Great Depression'', 1938, Econ History Review * ''Essays on the British Economy of the Nineteenth Century'', 1948. * ''The Terms of Trade in Theory and Practice'', 1950, Econ History Review * ''The Historical Analysis of Terms of Trade'', 1951, Econ History Review * ''The Process of Economic Growth'', 1952. * ''Growth and Fluctuations in the British Economy, 1790–1850: An Historical, Statistical, and Theoretical Study of Britain's Economic Development'', with Arthur Gayer and [[Anna Schwartz]], 1953 {{ISBN|0-06-492344-4}} * ''The Dynamics of Soviet Society'' (with others), Norton and Co. 1953, slight update Anchor edition 1954. * ''"Trends in the Allocation of Resources in Secular Growth'', 1955, in Dupriez, editor, Economic Progress * ''An American Policy in Asia'', with R.W. Hatch, 1955. * ''The Take-Off into Self-Sustained Growth'', 1956, EJ * ''A Proposal: Key to an effective foreign policy'', with [[Max Millikan]], 1957. * ''The Stages of Economic Growth'', 1959, Econ History Review * ''The Stages of Economic Growth: A non-communist manifesto'', 1960.{{cite book|author=Walt Whitman Rostow|title=The Stages of Economic Growth: A Non-Communist Manifesto|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=XzJdpd8DbYEC|year=1990|origyear=1960|publisher=Cambridge University Press|isbn=978-0-521-40928-5}} * ''The United States in the World Arena: An Essay in Recent History'' (American Project Series), 1960, 568 pages. * ''Politics and the Stages of Growth'', 1971. * ''How it All Began: Origins of the modern economy'', 1975. * ''The World Economy: History and prospect'', 1978. * ''Why the Poor Get Richer and the Rich Slow Down: Essays in the Marshallian long period'', 1980. * ''Eisenhower, Kennedy, and foreign aid'', 1985. * ''Theorists of Economic Growth from David Hume to the Present'', 1990. * ''The Great Population Spike and After'', 1998 ==See also== * ''[[The Best and the Brightest]]'' by [[David Halberstam]] * ''[[Hearts and Minds (film)]]'' ==References== {{reflist}} ==Further reading== *{{cite book |title=America's Rasputin: Walt Rostow and the Vietnam War |location=New York |publisher=Hill and Wang |year=2008 |first=David |last=Milne |isbn=978-0-374-10386-6 }} ==External links== * [http://texana.texascooking.com/news/waltrostowobituary.htm Rostow's obituary] * Hodgson, Godfrey. [https://www.theguardian.com/obituaries/story/0,3604,896940,00.html "Walt Rostow: Obituary"], in ''[[The Guardian]]'', February 17, 2003. * {{C-SPAN|waltrostow}} * [http://www.timesonline.co.uk/printFriendly/0,,1-45-582682,00.html "Walt Rostow: Obituary"], in [http://www.timesonline.co.uk/ ''The Times''], February 19, 2003. * [http://www.utexas.edu/faculty/council/2003-2004/memorials/rostow/rostow.html ''In Memoriam''], The University of Texas at Austin. * [http://www.lbjlib.utexas.edu/johnson/archives.hom/oralhistory.hom/rostow/rostow.asp Oral History Interviews with Walt Rostow, from the Lyndon Baines Johnson Library] * [http://www.wilsoncenter.org/walt-rostow Interview with Walt Rostow by Avner Cohen at The Nuclear Proliferation International History Project.] *{{cite web|title=W. W. Rostow |url=https://www.jstor.org/action/doBasicSearch?Query=au%3A%22W+W+Rostow%22+&acc=off&wc=on&fc=off&group=none|publisher=[[JSTOR]]}} {{s-start}} {{s-off}} {{s-new|office}} {{s-ttl|title=[[Deputy National Security Advisor (United States)|Deputy National Security Advisor]]|years=1961}} {{s-aft|after=[[Carl Kaysen]]}} |- {{s-bef|rows=2|before=[[George C. page.title: Women in the Israel Defense Forces

revision.comment: /* War of Independence */ Added link for Gurion
revision.text:
[[File:Flickr - Israel Defense Forces - Female Infantry Instructors Prepare for a Combat Exercise, Nov 2010.jpg|thumb|Female infantry instructors prepare for a combat exercise]] [[File:Flickr - Israel Defense Forces - 163rd IAF Flight Course Graduates (1).jpg|thumb|Graduates of [[Israeli Air Force]] Flight Course]] [[File:Flickr - Israel Defense Forces - Guns N' Roses, Welcome to the Home Front Jungle.jpg|thumb| Female soldier of the Search and Rescue Unit during combat training]] [[File:Ancocourse3456664433.JPG|thumb|IDF Warrant Officers' training]] The '''women in the Israel Defense Forces''' are [[woman|female]] soldiers who serve in the [[Israel Defense Forces]]. [[Israel]] is one of only a few countries in the world with a [[Conscription in Israel|mandatory military service requirement]] for women.<ref name=serviceStatsAugust2010>{{cite web|title=Statistics: Women’s Service in the IDF for 2010, 25 Aug 2010|url=http://idfspokesperson.com/2010/08/25/statistics-womens-service-in-the-idf-for-2010-25-aug-2010/|publisher=Israel Defense Forces|accessdate=22 March 2011|date=25 August 2010}}</ref><ref name="feldinger">{{cite news | first= Lauren Gelfond | last=Feldinger | title = Skirting history | publisher= The Jerusalem Post | accessdate=2011-03-22 | date = September 21, 2008 | url = http://www.jpost.com/Home/Article.aspx?id=114834 }}</ref><ref name=mfaWomen>{{cite web|title=Integration of women in the IDF|publisher=Israeli Ministry of Foreign Affairs|url=http://www.mfa.gov.il/MFA/Israel+beyond+politics/Integration_women_in_IDF-March_2009 | accessdate=23 March 2011|date=8 March 2009}}</ref>
According to the IDF, 535 female Israeli soldiers had been killed in combat operations between the period 1962-2016 (this figure does not include the dozens of female soldiers killed in Israeli service prior to 1962).<ref name="auto">{{cite web|url=http://www.haaretz.com/israel-news/1.719038?v=BDD11CFC5DFD7E6A2F0CD56A63DF587A|title=Israeli Woman Who Broke Barriers Downed by Hezbollah Rocket as 2006 Combat Volunteer|first=Gili|last=Cohen|date=10 May 2016|publisher=|accessdate=12 August 2017|via=Haaretz}}</ref> Women have taken part in Israel’s military before and since the founding of the state in 1948,<ref name=womenIDF>{{cite web|title=Women in the IDF|url=http://idfspokesperson.com/2011/03/07/women-in-the-idf/|publisher=Israel Defense Forces|accessdate=22 March 2011|date=7 March 2011}}</ref><ref name="60YearsService">{{cite web|title=60 Years of Women’s Service in the IDF|url=http://idfspokesperson.com/reports/60-years-of-women%E2%80%99s-service-in-the-idf/|publisher=Israel Defense Forces|accessdate=22 March 2011}}</ref> with women comprising over 20% of Israeli forces in 1948, and 33% of all IDF soldiers and 51% of its officers, in 2011,<ref name=dotzNov11>{{cite press_release | url= http://www.idf.il/1086-14000-EN/Dover.aspx | title=More female officers in more positions in the IDF | publisher=[[IDF spokesperson]] | date=30 November 2011 |accessdate=8 December 2011}}</ref> fulfilling various roles within the [[GOC Army Headquarters|Ground]], [[Israeli Navy|Navy]] and [[Israeli air force|Air]] Forces. The 2000 Equality amendment to the Military Service law states that "The right of women to serve in any role in the IDF is equal to the right of men."<ref name=mfaWomen /> As of now, 88% to 92%<ref name=idfWomen2012>{{cite web | url=http://www.idf.il/1589-en/Dover.aspx |title=Women of the IDF | publisher=[[IDF Spokesperson's Unit]] | accessdate=22 January 2012}}</ref> of all roles in the IDF are open to female candidates, while women can be found in 69% of all positions.<ref name=serviceStatsAugust2010 />
Up until 2001 women conscripts served in the [[Women's Affairs advisor#History|Women's Corps]], commonly known by its Hebrew acronym, '''CHEN'''. After a five-week period of basic training they served as clerks, drivers, welfare workers, nurses, radio operators, flight controllers, ordnance personnel, and course instructors.<ref name="lcweb2.loc.gov">{{cite web|url=http://lcweb2.loc.gov/cgi-bin/query/r?frd/cstdy:@field%28DOCID+il0168%29 |title=Israel |publisher=Lcweb2.loc.gov |date= |accessdate=2014-04-22}}</ref>
==History== ===Pre-independence=== [[File:Mishmar HaEmek.JPG|thumb|left|Women training at [[Mishmar HaEmek]], during the [[1947–48 Civil War in Mandatory Palestine]]]] [[File:Haganah Woman.jpg|200px|thumb|A female officer of the [[Haganah]] demonstrates handling a [[Sten]] gun during the [[1948 Arab–Israeli War]]]]
Before the establishment of the state, women served in combat roles in the militias that [[Israel Defense Forces#History|would become]] the Israel Defense Forces.<ref name=60YearsService /> The rate of women who took part in combat organizations stood at 20%.<ref name=mfaWomen /> At the years before the establishment of the IDF, military service for women existed in the lines of the [[Hashomer]] and [[Haganah]] organizations. The Haganah stated in its law that its lines were open to: "Every Jewish male or female, who is prepared and trained to fulfill the obligation of national defense." Most served as medics, communications specialists, and weaponeers. During WWII approximately 4,000 females volunteered for service in the British assisting forces. One of them, Alice Hatzor-Hirsch, was about 16 when she joined the Hagana. In 1942, she joined the [[British army]] as a driver. "We were more connected than the others," she recalled years later. "A girl becoming a driver in the British army was considered the height of boldness at the time."<ref name=womanValor>{{cite web|last=Ben-Ari|first=Bar|title=A Woman of Valor|url=http://dover.idf.il/IDF/English/News/Up_Close/2007/08/0101.htm|publisher=Israel Defense Forces|accessdate=23 March 2011|date=1 August 2007}}</ref>
In [[Tel-Aviv]] of the 1940s, a battalion was established in which women filled positions in security, weapons transport, and manned anti-aircraft posts. During the winter of 1948, women joined the combat soldiers of the [[Palmach]], who traveled from Tel Aviv to [[Jerusalem]] with their weapons concealed in their clothes. The Palmach arm (thirty percent of which were females) trained nine female platoon commanders, and other female squad commanders.<ref name=womanValor />
===War of Independence=== On 26 May 1948, Prime Minister [[David Ben Gurion]] officially set up the IDF as the country's army. On 18 August 1948, mandatory conscription for single and married women without children (born between the years 1920-1930) began.<ref name=idfBeg>{{cite web | url=http://www.idf.il/1283-9679-en/Dover.aspx | title=The Beginning, Women in the Early IDF | publisher=[[IDF Spokesperson]] | date=7 March 2011 | accessdate=14 August 2011}}</ref>
Women served in many positions including nurses, signal operators, drivers, clerks, cooks and more. The Women's Corps, under which all women served, was responsible for taking care of women soldiers' needs and for their training and integration into different IDF units. The Women's Corps also sent young women soldiers to be teachers in developing areas and immigrant neighborhoods of Israel.<ref name=idfBeg />
===Post-independence=== [[File:IDF women officers 1950.jpg|thumb|right|Female soldiers in 1950]] [[File:Wwwm8173.JPG|thumb|An [[Uzi]]-armed Israeli on guard duty in the [[Negev]] (1956).]] [[File:PikiWiki Israel 21504 IDF women soldiers.jpg|thumb|IDF women soldiers between 1953 and 1954]] Apart from the [[1948 Arab-Israeli War]], when manpower shortages saw many Palmach and IDF women taking active part in land battles, women were historically barred from battle in the IDF, serving in a variety of technical and administrative support roles. Soon after the establishment of the IDF, the removal of all women from front-line positions was decreed. Decisive for this decision was the very real possibility of falling into enemy hands as [[prisoners of war]]. It was fair and equitable to demand from women equal sacrifice and risk, it was argued, but the risk for women prisoners of [[rape]] and [[Sexual assault|sexual molestation]] was infinitely greater than the same risk for men.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.mfa.gov.il/MFA/Facts+About+Israel/State/The+Israel+Defense+Forces.htm |title=SPOTLIGHT ON ISRAEL: The Israel Defense Forces|publisher=[[Israel Ministry of Foreign Affairs]] |author=Dr. Netanel Lorch |date=May 31, 1997 |accessdate=2010-06-10}}</ref> A majority of women serving in the IDF then were secretaries. The rest served primarily as instructors, nurses, clerks and telephone operators. A few women flew transport missions in the 1950s and a few women were accepted into flight training in the 1970s, but did not complete the program before it was closed to women.<ref name="feldinger"/> {{quotebox|align=left|width=220px|quote=The army is the supreme symbol of duty and as long as women are not equal to men in performing this duty, they have not yet obtained true equality. If the daughters of Israel are absent from the army, then the character of the [[Yishuv]] will be distorted.|source=[[David Ben-Gurion]], first [[Israeli Prime Minister]]<ref name=idfBeg />}} [[Yael Rom]], the first female pilot trained by the Israeli Air Force, earned her wings in 1951.<ref name="IAFwomandies">{{cite news|url=http://www.jweekly.com/article/full/29471/first-woman-pilot-in-israeli-air-force-dies/ |title=First woman pilot in Israeli Air Force dies|publisher=The Jewish news weekly of Northern California |date=June 2, 2006 |accessdate=2010-06-10}}</ref> Hava Inbar, a lawyer, was appointed the judge of the military court in Haifa in September 1969, thus becoming the first female military judge in the world. "I do not know if I want to be a military judge my whole life," she said in an interview, "but I am glad that I was appointed; it proves that the IDF leaves almost all doors open for its female soldiers."<ref name=womanValor />
[[File:PikiWiki_Israel_12768_IDF_parade_in_Jerusalem_in_1968.jpg|thumb|IDF female soldiers on parade, Jerusalem, 1968]] During the [[Yom Kippur War]], due to a growing need for ground forces, women were needed in roles in the field.<ref name=60YearsService /> According to Rina Bar-Tal, chair of the Israel Women's Network, roles for women beyond technical and secretarial support only started to open up in the late 1970s and early '80s, because of manpower shortages. Since then, a few women have earned ranks higher than colonel. In 1986, [[Amira Dotan]], then head of the Women's Corps, became the first female brigadier-general.<ref name="feldinger"/>
==Gender equality== [[File:Flickr - Israel Defense Forces - First Ethiopian Ordnance Officer in Israeli History.jpg|thumb|left|upright=0.6|First IDF ordnance officer of [[Ethiopian Jews|Ethiopian Jewish]] origin]] [[File:Flickr - Israel Defense Forces - Field Training Week for Ground Forces (3).jpg|thumb|180px|IDF infantry instructors course]] Civilian pilot and aeronautical engineer Alice Miller successfully petitioned the [[Israeli Supreme Court|High Court of Justice]] to take the Israeli Air Force pilot training exams, after being rejected on grounds of gender. Though president [[Ezer Weizman]], a former IAF commander, told Miller that she'd be better off staying home and darning socks, the court eventually ruled in 1996 that the IAF could not exclude qualified women from pilot training. Even though Miller would not pass the exams, the ruling was a watershed, opening doors for women in new IDF roles. Female legislators took advantage of the momentum to draft a bill allowing women to volunteer for any position, if they could qualify.<ref name="feldinger"/>
In 2000, the Equality amendment to the Military Service law stated that "The right of women to serve in any role in the IDF is equal to the right of men."<ref name=mfaWomen /> The amendment that female lawmakers had drafted granted equal opportunities to women found physically and personally suitable for a job. The question of who and what was "suitable" was left to the discretion of military leaders on a case-by-case basis. Women did start to enter combat support and light combat roles in a few areas, including the Artillery Corps, infantry units and armored divisions. A few platoons named [[Caracal Battalion|Carakal]] were formed for men and women to serve together in light infantry. By 2000 Carakal became a full-fledged battalion. Many women would also join the [[Israeli Border Police|Border Police]].<ref name="feldinger"/>
The first female jet fighter pilot, [[Roni Zuckerman]], received her wings in 2001.<ref name="IAFwomandies" /> By 2006, the first female pilots and navigators graduated from the IAF training course, and several hundred women entered combat units, primarily in support roles, like intelligence gatherers, instructors, social workers, medics and engineers. When the [[Second Lebanon War]] broke out, it was the first time since 1948 that women were in field operations alongside men. Airborne helicopter engineer Sgt.-Maj. (res.) Keren Tendler was the first female IDF combat soldier to be killed in action.<ref name="feldinger"/> In November 2007 the Air Force appointed its first woman deputy squadron commander.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.haaretz.com/news/israel-air-force-appoints-first-female-deputy-squadron-commander-1.234139 |title=Israel Air Force appoints first female deputy squadron commander |publisher=Haaretz.com |author=Yuval Azoulay |date=November 28, 2007 |accessdate=2010-06-10}}</ref>
On 23 June 2011, [[Orna Barbivai]] became the first female [[Aluf|Major-General]] in the IDF upon her promotion to the role of commander of the [[Manpower Directorate]]. She is the second woman to serve on the General Staff.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-4074563,00.html|title=IDF names first female major general|newspaper=[[Yediot Ahronot]]|date=26 May 2011|first=Hanan|last=Greenberg}}</ref><ref name=idfPromotionAlufa>{{cite web | work=IDF Spokesperson's Blog | date=23 June 2011 | accessdate=4 July 2011 | title=Israeli Army Celebrates First Female Major General | publisher=IDF Spokesperson | url=http://idfspokesperson.com/2011/06/23/israeli-army-celebrates-first-ever-female-major-general/}}</ref> In 2012, Capitan Merav Buchris became the first female ammunition Officer in the Air force,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.iaf.org.il/4379-38661-en/IAF.aspx |title=The Israeli Air Force : First Time Around |publisher=Iaf.org.il |date=2012-02-27 |accessdate=2014-04-22}}</ref> she started her military career as a [[Shoher]] at the [[Israeli Air And Space technical college|Technical Academy]] in [[Haifa]]. In 2013, in a first, a female IDF soldier was called up to the Torah during a service on a military base.<ref>{{cite web|last=Newman |first=Marissa |url=http://www.timesofisrael.com/female-soldier-called-up-to-torah-on-military-base/ |title=Female soldier called up to Torah on military base |publisher=The Times of Israel |date=2013-09-30 |accessdate=2014-04-22}}</ref> Also in 2013, the IDF announced they would, for the first time, allow a (MTF) transgender woman to serve in the army as a female soldier.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://awiderbridge.org/transgender-in-the-idf/#sthash.ZAUcxHOz.dpuf |title=Transgender in the IDF |publisher=AWiderBridge |date=2013-08-07 |accessdate=2014-04-22}}</ref>
In 2014, there were several more firsts for women in the IDF. The IDF appointed Major Oshrat Bacher as Israel's first female combat battalion commander;<ref name="algemeiner.com">{{cite web|last=Ben-Zvi|first=Gidon|title=First Lady: IDF Appoints First Female Combat Battalion Commander|url=http://www.algemeiner.com/2014/01/02/first-lady-idf-appoints-first-female-combat-battalion-commander/|work=[[Algemeiner Journal]]|publisher=[[Simon Jacobson]]|accessdate=15 January 2014|location=Brooklyn, New York, United States|date=2 January 2014|quote=History was made on Wednesday when the Israel Defense Forces appointed Major Oshrat Bacher as Israel’s first female combat battalion commander, Israeli daily Ma’ariv reports.}}</ref> Dr. Shani became the first female combat doctor in an elite counterterror unit in the IDF (specifically, the Duvdevan counterterrorism unit);<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.israelhayom.com/site/newsletter_article.php?id=14617 |title=IDF welcomes first female combat doctor in elite counterterror unit |publisher=Israel Hayom |date=2014-01-09 |accessdate=2014-04-22}}</ref> and the IDF decided to allow female kosher supervisors to work in its kitchens on military bases.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://forward.com/articles/190635/idf-to-allow-female-kosher-supervisors-to-work-on/ |title=IDF To Allow Female Kosher Supervisors To Work on Military Bases – |publisher=Forward.com |date=2014-01-09 |accessdate=2014-04-22}}</ref>
==Service== Mandatory service for women in the IDF is 24 months, apart from roles specified in law which require a service length of 36 months.<ref name=olimalmadim>{{cite web|title=Service Length for Women|url=http://www.aka.idf.il/giyus/general/?catid=12943&docid=30365|publisher=Israeli Defense Forces|language=Hebrew|accessdate=23 March 2011}}</ref> Women may be exempted from military service for reasons of religious conscience, marriage, pregnancy, or motherhood. A woman may receive an exemption on religious grounds under the following conditions:<ref name=moia>{{cite web|title=Military Service 2nd Edition|url=http://www.moia.gov.il/NR/rdonlyres/DBF4B5CB-861F-492B-A74B-D31528817568/0/idf_en.pdf|publisher=Israeli Ministry of Immigrant Absorption|accessdate=23 March 2011}}</ref> # She has declared that for reasons of conscience, or a religious way of life, she is prevented from doing military service and has proven this to the satisfaction of the exemption committee. # She keeps the laws of [[Kashrut]] at home and outside. # She does not travel on [[Shabbat]]. Women who arrive in Israel at age 17 and over are generally exempt from army service, but may serve on a voluntary basis. Also, women (who are not fighters) are not generally called up for reserve duty if they are married, or if they are beyond age 24.<ref name=moia />
==Combat roles== [[File:Flickr - Israel Defense Forces - A Deserved Decoration.jpg|thumb|[[Anastasia Bagdalov]], awarded a military commendation for her role during the 2011 Sinai attacks. A passenger on the bus, she used her T-shirt and another passenger's bra<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.jns.org/latest-articles/2013/11/10/just-do-your-job-trainer-of-idf-paramedics-on-life-saving-improvisation|title=‘Just do your job’: Trainer of IDF paramedics on life-saving improvisation|publisher=|accessdate=12 August 2017}}</ref> as tourniquets to save the life of a severely wounded soldier.]] [[File:Flickr - Israel Defense Forces - Female Soldiers Practice Shooting (1).jpg|thumb|Female soldiers of the [[Israel Defense Forces]] in training]] Clause 16A of the military service law requires that female combat soldiers serve 2 years and 4 months of mandatory service, and continue in reserves service up to age 38.<ref name=serviceStatsAugust2010 /> Each year, 1,500 female combat soldiers are drafted into the IDF.<ref name=womenIDF /> Women currently make up 3% of the IDF's combat soldiers.<ref name=dotzNov11 /> Women were employed in full combat roles during the War of Independence and early years. An incident involving the abuse of a woman's corpse led to their withdrawal from full combat<ref name="auto"/> until 2000, when the Caracal Battalion was raised.
In 2014, the IDF appointed Major Oshrat Bacher as Israel’s first female combat battalion commander.<ref name="algemeiner.com"/>
The most notable combat option for women is the [[Caracal Battalion]], which is a light infantry force that is made up of 70 percent female soldiers.<ref name=mfaWomen /> The unit undergoes combat infantry training.<ref name=womenIDF /> There are two other mixed-sex infantry battalions: the Lions of Jordan Battalion and the Bardelas Battalion. The IDF commando K9 unit, [[Oketz]], also drafts females as combat soldiers.<ref name=dotzNov11 /> Women are also allowed to join the [[Combat Intelligence Collection Corps]], and to serve as Search and Rescue personnel in the IDF [[Home Front Command]]'s Search and Rescue Force, officially classified as a combat unit. A pilot program currently being tested has women serving in tanks.
Despite being officially classified as combat soldiers, women in combat roles are not deliberately deployed into combat situations. They are expected to respond in the event a combat situation does erupt, but are not deployed to situations where there is a high risk of combat. The three mixed-sex infantry battalions are deployed to border patrol duties on the Israeli borders with Egypt and Jordan and security duties in the Jordan Valley, and female infantry soldiers are barred from joining the frontline combat infantry brigades which are deployed in the event of war. Female tank crews, who are also only regulated to border guard duties, do not serve in the regular armored combat units.<ref>https://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-5089566,00.html</ref><ref>https://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-5047996,00.html</ref>
==Women's affairs advisor== {{main| Women's Affairs advisor}} [[File:Flickr - Israel Defense Forces - Female Soldier Aiming her Weapon.jpg|thumb|The Field Training Week in Southern Israel, part of the IDF Infantry Instructors course (2006)]] The Women's Corps was dismantled in 2000, so that female soldiers for the first time would fall under the authority of individual units based on jobs and not on gender. They would wear the insignia of their units instead of the insignia of the Women's Corps.<ref name="feldinger"/> The position of Women's Affairs Advisor to the Chief of Staff was created in 2001. The female officer holding the position is in charge of ensuring more opportunities and a suitable environment for female soldiers, as well as better enhancing their skills. The mission of the advisor is described by the IDF as "empowering women, the IDF and Israeli society by promoting conditions that allow for the optimal use of the capabilities of women serving in the IDF; promoting equal opportunities for women during their military service; and assimilating women into military leadership positions."<ref name=dotzNov11 />
== Service exemptions == Sixty–five percent of Israeli women serve in the army, 25 percent opt out on religious grounds, the remainder are exempted for physical, emotional or marital reasons.<ref>Anne R. Bloom: Women in the Defense Forces, in: Swirski, Barbara und Safir, Marylin P.: Calling the equality bluff – Women in Israel, New York 1991, p. 141.</ref> A law passed in 1978 made exemptions for women on religious grounds automatic upon the signing of a simple declaration attesting to the observance of orthodox religious practices. This legislation raised considerable controversy, and IDF officials feared that the exemption could be abused by any nonreligious woman who did not wish to serve and thus further exacerbate the already strained personnel resources of the IDF. Women exempted on religious grounds were legally obliged to fulfill a period of alternative service doing social or educational work assigned to them. In practice, however, women performed such service only on a voluntary basis.<ref name="lcweb2.loc.gov"/>
==2007 Segev Committee report== [[File:Flickr - Israel Defense Forces - The Life of Female Field Intelligence Combat Soldiers (3).jpg|thumb|Field intelligence combat unit]] [[File:Flickr - Israel Defense Forces - First Female Reconnaissance Company.jpg|thumb|A graduate of the first reconnaissance company composed of female combat soldiers in the IDF (2007)]]
In 2007, then Head of Manpower Directorate, Aluf (Maj. Gen.) [[Elazar Stern]], appointed a committee to define women's service in the IDF in the next decade, with the objective of increasing equal opportunities in women's service in the IDF.<ref name=mfaWomen/> The committee, headed by Maj. Gen. (res.) Yehuda Segev, submitted its report to Stern in September 2007.<ref name=commisionFrzHaaretz>{{cite news |url=http://www.haaretz.com/print-edition/news/idf-freezes-implementation-of-report-calling-for-gender-equality-1.398544 | title=IDF freezes implementation of report calling for gender equality | newspaper=[[Haaretz]] | first=Amos | last=Harel | date=30 November 2011 | accessdate=30 November 2011}}</ref>
In September 2008, the 100-page report was presented to the IDF General Staff. [[Rav Aluf]] [[Gabi Ashkenazi]], then-[[Chief of General Staff (Israel)|Chief of Staff]], voiced support for the committee's vision:<ref name=mfaWomen /><blockquote>The IDF, as a leading organization in Israeli society, designates the service of men and women to a fulfilling and respectful service based upon equal opportunities in the service of [the] IDF and the State of Israel.</blockquote>
[[File:Flickr - Israel Defense Forces - Caracal Battalion Conducts Concluding Exercise (2).jpg|thumb|left|upright|[[Caracal Battalion]] training]] The committee called for the annulment of the model that has been in place since the 1950s, under which a soldier's length of service and service options is largely determined by gender. "This is an archaic model that causes under-utilization of the resources ... of half of Israeli society, and closes off many opportunities, both during service and for integrating into society after service," the report said.<ref name=commisionFrzHaaretz />
In 2007, 12 percent of all army jobs were completely closed to women. The report partially attributed it to the shorter length of service, as a barrier to putting women in the most demanding and important jobs. Hence postings are "to a large extent" determined by gender rather than a soldier's talents and abilities. Instead, the length of service "should depend solely on the job, rather than on one's gender."<ref name=commisionFrzHaaretz />
The report advised making it harder for women to get an exemption from mandatory service and curbing the phenomenon of women falsely claiming exemptions on religious grounds. It also said the criteria for exemptions from service should be the same for both men and women.<ref name=commisionFrzHaaretz /> The panel recommended mandatory quotas for promoting women, with the goal of giving women a "significant presence" in the army's "senior decision-making ranks." In addition, it called for creating an effective, well-funded system to ensure proper working environments for both men and women, and for drafting a "gender code" that would lay down explicit rules for interaction between the sexes. "There should be no jobs or units categorically closed to either women or men," it said. "Service in all units, postings and missions would be joint, subject to the rules of appropriate integration."<ref name=commisionFrzHaaretz />
The committee proposed opening all jobs to women aside from a handful to be determined by a special committee, whose decisions would require the approval of the Chief of Staff, the [[Israeli Defense Minister|Defense Minister]] and the [[Knesset]] Foreign Affairs and Defense Committee. It said the initial screening and assignment process should be unified so that men and women are part of the same system and receive their assignments based on the same criteria, including for acceptance into combat units. The panel proposed implementing this change gradually over the course of a decade.<ref name=commisionFrzHaaretz />
== Issues == [[File:Aaaancocourse3453422275.JPG|thumb|Female cadets training with the [[IWI Tavor]] assault rifle, during Warrant Officer course, as part of a special law course.]] [[File:Flickr - Israel Defense Forces - Pose for the Camera.jpg|thumb|Soldiers of the Caracal mixed gender battalion during a platoon exercise in southern Israel]]
===Religious objections=== In 1950 chief rabbis [[Yitzhak HaLevi Herzog]] and [[Ben-Zion Meir Hai Uziel]] issued a ruling forbidding women to join the IDF.<ref name="auto1">{{cite web|url=http://www.jpost.com/Defense/Rabbinical-association-says-permissible-in-Jewish-law-for-women-to-enlist-to-IDF-354648|title=Rabbinical association says permissible in Jewish law for women to serve in IDF|publisher=}}</ref> In the 1980s Rabbi [[Meir Kahane]] ardently opposed women serving in the [[Israel Defense Forces|IDF]], advocating [[sherut leumi|national service]] instead.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Kahane|first1=Meir|title=Women in the IDF|url=http://mkwords.com/text/index.php?i=96&a=Women%20in%20the%20IDF|website=mkwords.com}}</ref> As of 2014 [[David Lau]] and [[Yitzhak Yosef]] of the Chief Rabbinate were opposed to religious women serving in the IDF, as was Safed Chief Rabbi [[Shmuel Eliyahu]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.jpost.com/Diplomacy-and-Politics/Lapid-Fire-Chief-Rabbis-over-objection-to-religious-womens-service-in-the-army-337775 |title=Lapid: Fire Chief Rabbis over objection to religious women's service in the army | JPost | Israel News |publisher=JPost |date=2013-02-05 |accessdate=2014-04-22}}</ref> However, Finance Minister [[Yair Lapid]] opposes this position and wants Lau and Yosef to be removed from the Chief Rabbinate because of it. Economy Minister [[Naftali Bennett]] stated "I believe that all girls should do either IDF service or national service. With that, the attack on the rabbis for their traditional position is an unacceptable attack on the respect due them."<ref name="haaretz1">{{cite web|last=Lis |first=Jonathan |url=http://www.haaretz.com/news/national/.premium-1.568410 |title=Israeli ministers spar over women serving in army - National Israel News |publisher=Haaretz |date=2014-01-13 |accessdate=2014-04-22}}</ref> Education Minister [[Shai Piron]] said he backs the chief rabbis' injunction against observant women enlisting in the IDF.<ref>{{cite web|last=Newman |first=Marissa |url=http://www.timesofisrael.com/education-minister-backs-rabbis-ban-on-female-enlistment/#ixzz2sx3SWG2M |title=Education minister backs rabbis' ban on Orthodox women in IDF |publisher=The Times of Israel |date=2014-01-13 |accessdate=2014-04-22}}</ref> In 2003 Piron had said, “I don’t know of any rabbis that would allow [observant women] to serve in the army. The halachic authorities saw the reality from a joint education and spiritual perspective, this view led them to their halachic conclusion… The problem with IDF service is the general atmosphere that does not allow for a life without [religious] pitfalls.”<ref>{{cite web|last=Newman |first=Marissa |url=http://www.timesofisrael.com/education-minister-backs-rabbis-ban-on-female-enlistment/#ixzz2sx4Pn79B |title=Education minister backs rabbis' ban on Orthodox women in IDF |publisher=The Times of Israel |date=2014-01-13 |accessdate=2014-04-22}}</ref> MK [[Elazar Stern]] said, "A week ago the Chief Rabbis announced that a female serving in the IDF results in an [[aveira]] similar to [[Dishonor|Chilul]] [[Shabbat|Shabbos]]. This is tantamount to issuing a call to women, at least those who view themselves as religious, not to serve in the IDF...I served in the IDF for a few years and I state the military cannot function without women unless we lengthen the service of males to 4.5 years. The price that we will pay by the call of the Chief Rabbinate Council that females do not enlist is not that of our daughters, but the daughters of these very same rabbis who don't serve."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.theyeshivaworld.com/news/headlines-breaking-stories/210612/stern-joins-lapid-in-condemning-the-chief-rabbis.html#sthash.8LEBOSwN.dpuf |title=The Yeshiva World Stern Joins Lapid in Condemning the Chief Rabbis « » Frum Jewish News |publisher=Theyeshivaworld.com |date=2014-01-16 |accessdate=2014-04-22}}</ref> Rabbi [[Shlomo Riskin]], the Rabbi of the city of [[Efrat]], supports women's enlistment in the IDF.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.israelnationalnews.com/News/News.aspx/176571#.Uvjg65uPKM8 |title=Rabbi Riskin on Women’s Enlistment: It's a Mitzvah - Jewish World - News |publisher=Israel National News |date=2014-01-21 |accessdate=2014-04-22}}</ref> Also, in 2014 the Beit Hillel association of national-religious rabbis issued a ruling in Jewish law stating that women are allowed to serve in the IDF; however, Rabbi [[Shlomo Aviner]] claimed that Beit Hillel did not have the authority to make such a ruling.<ref name="auto1"/>
Observant Jewish women are allowed to do national service instead of enlisting in the IDF.<ref name="haaretz1"/>
The IDF offers [[Haredim]] men "women free and secular free" recruitment centers. Defense Minister Moshe Ya'alon expressed his willingness to relax regulations to meet the demands of ultra-Orthodox rabbis. Regulations regarding gender equality had already been relaxed so that Haredim could be assured that men would not receive physical exams from female medical staff.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-4586197,00.html|title=IDF offers haredim 'women-free' recruitment centers|publisher=|accessdate=12 August 2017}}</ref>
===Sexual harassment=== In ''Israel and Its Army: From Cohesion to Confusion'', Stuart A. Cohen has argued that prior to the 1990s, there had existed a general consensus in the IDF that "sexual prowess goes hand in hand with military accomplishment." Even when social attitudes were changing in the 1980s, the IDF was still inclined towards tolerance and a senior army official warned of not blowing the "topic out of all proportion."<ref>Stuart A. Cohen. ''Israel and Its Army: From Cohesion to Confusion'', pg. 66-67</ref> In 1993, the ''[[Maariv]]'' reported that only 10% of around 1,000 reported cases of sexual harassment each year are investigated.<ref>[[Susan Starr Sered]]. "A Cultural Climate in the IDF That Legitimises Sexual Harassment of Women Soldiers", in ''What Makes Women Sick?: Maternity, Modesty, and Militarism in Israeli Society'', UPNE, 2000. pg. 92</ref> Reports of sexual harassment against women in the Israeli army reached an average of one a day in 1999, an increase on the 280 complainants received in 1997. In 1998-99, 54 officers were expelled from the army on such charges, others faced demotion or prison. In one high-profile case, General Yitzchak Mordechai was charged with sexual assault and harassment. Another case involved the promotion of General Nir Galili after being accused of grooming a young female recruit for intimate relations. This issue has led the Israeli military to being described by the feminist American writer [[Laura Sjoberg]] as a "hothouse for exploitive sexual relationships" and a force whose fighting culture is based on "rampant licentiousness."<ref>Laura Sjoberg, Sandra Via. ''Gender, War, and Militarism: Feminist Perspectives'' (2010). pg. 87</ref> While the army has since tried to curb sexual harassment, it remains a problem. In 2004, it was reported that 1 in 5 women soldiers suffer sexual harassment.<ref>Stuart A. Cohen Israel and Its Army: From Cohesion to Confusion pg. 68</ref>
===Singing controversy=== {{main|Tzniut#Female singing voice}} In September 2011, because of a religious ban on men hearing women sing,<ref>Rabbi [[Eliezer Melamed]], [http://revivimen.yhb.org.il/2012/01/13/military-orders-that-contradict-jewish-law/ Military Orders that Contradict Jewish Law]</ref> nine religiously-observant cadets in the IDF officer's course walked out of an evening seminar on the legacy of the 2008 [[Operation Cast Lead]] in [[Gaza Strip|Gaza]] when a band comprising two male and two female vocalists took the stage to sing. The commander of the school expelled four of them, after they said they would disobey orders again. The IDF agreed to re-examine regulations on this issue, given the growing number of [[Haredi]] soldiers in combat units.<ref name=singHAaretzSep11>{{cite news |title=IDF: Soldiers cannot skip ceremonies with women singing |author=Amos Harel|url=http://www.haaretz.com/print-edition/news/idf-soldiers-cannot-skip-ceremonies-with-women-singing-1.384288 |newspaper=Haaretz |date=2011-09-14|accessdate=2011-12-31}}</ref> In October 2011, women soldiers were ordered to leave a post-[[Simhat Torah]] celebration on orders from IDF rabbis, and asked to dance in a separate area.<ref name=singHaaretzNov11>{{cite news |title=Top settler rabbi: Soldiers will sooner choose death than suffer women's singing |author=Yair Ettinger|url=http://www.haaretz.com/news/national/top-settler-rabbi-soldiers-will-sooner-choose-death-than-suffer-women-s-singing-1.396180 |newspaper=Haaretz|date=2011-11-17 |accessdate=2011-12-31}}</ref> In November 2011, nineteen reserve Major Generals sent a protest letter to Defense Minister [[Ehud Barak]] and IDF Chief of Staff Benny Gantz and warned against harming the motivation of women to serve in the army and undermining "the fundamental values of Israeli society." <ref name=singHaaretzNov11 />
